Chavez Appeals to
Court of Last Resorts
by Reuben Gobezie
Cesar Chavez, president of the
United Farm Workers of
America (AFWA), made an appeal to the public, "the court of
last resorts," to boycott grapes at
a talk on Monday, March 4. His
appearance is part of a ten day
tour of the East Coast.
Chavez is also trying to force
the grape growers of California
to stop their use of pesticides on
the fields, which appear to be
causing adverse affects on the
health of many of the field
workers and their families. He
noted a clear health risk to the
public who consumes grapes.
Chavez is turning to the public
for boycotting as a last resort after
many failed, attempts to have
government authorities in
California pass legislation that
would ban the use of pesticides
on the fields. However, his attempts of late have been unsuccessful, despite the opposition of
the 60,000 field workers in
California and the supporters in
the communities around the
grapelands in California.
Many communities throughout
California's grapelands are
against the grape owners because
of the very powerful lobby goups
that the producers have in the
California legislature, Chavez
said. In the past, Chavez's
boycott rallies have been successful in having legislation

passed that inhibited the use of
certain pesticides, such as DDT,
on grape fields and workers.
However, that was a shortlived success. After Governor
George Dukemajen became
governor of California, he
restrained the enforcement of
legislation preventing the use of
pesticides on California fields.
Chavez attributed this in part to
the fact that Governor Deukmajen's election campaign was
largely paid for by the grape
owners of California and their
supportive groups.
Despite such powerful political
opposition, Chavez said that the
grape boycott would only have to
influence nine percent of the consumers in order to have the grape
owners turn an open ear to the
people and reconsider their use of
pesticides on California fields, as
opposed to an unattainable fiftyone percent majority vote in the
California houses of legislature.
"The solution is simple," said
Chavez, "every time you go to
the market don't buy any
grapes—you're voting. And in a
boycott, you can vote more than
once."
Chavez said that the California
field workers and their families
are suffering from several health
hazards due to their exposure to
pesticides. Most prominent
among these health hazards are
birth defects among children

Recycling Program
Trashes Newspapers
by Jack Lipkin
"Do not bring your newspapers to be recycled," said Tim
Guiles, who is in charge of the
University recycling project.
"Until we say it's good," he added, "it's trash."
Guiles explained that a common misconception exists on
campus that newspaper is among
the materials recycled by the
University. Early last year, when
the recycling project took off,
newspaper was a big hit, Guiles
said. The system at Hopkins,
however, was incapable of handling the influx of newspaper.
Guiles said that newspaper
removal cost $15 per ton plus a
"tremendous" number of man
hours, which hampered the
recycling project as a whole.
"The American public is consuming newspaper at a rate which
cannot be recycled," said Guiles,
adding that "We didn't have
anything to support the structure." As a result, newspaper
recycling at Hopkins was
abandoned.
Although Guiles said that he
and his co-workers posted signs
announcing the elimination of
newspaper recycling, people continued to place newspapers in the
recycling bins and in the shed
behind AMR I. As a result,
Guiles said that he and his staff
were forced to dispose of the
papers in the regular trash
dumpsters.
"We need to find a way to keep
newspapers from entering the
University,". he said. While
Guiles has developed a recycling
proposal that would include
newspaper and other forms of
low-grade paper (cardboard,
:glossy paper, and junk mail) in
the recycling project once again,
this proposal will not take effect
for some time. In his "Status
Report 2/7/91," Guiles stated,

"The University can save more
that $10,000 each year by recycling its low grade wastestream
component."
He also explained in the report
that "If the conversion to [canvas] bags [from barrels] takes
place. . .there would be very little impact on the inner workings
of the recycling program. We
propose that, instead of buying
more recycling barrels for each
office on campus, we go through
each of the departments on campus and selectively relabel approximately half of the already
existing trash cans to accept
only low-grade paper."
Guiles' conclusion was that
University custodians would then
be able to collect low-grade paper
easily along with their normal
load of trash. He did say,
however, that there had been
"some trouble convincing custodians to empty all barrels to the

President Richardson holds an open forum for students to voice concerns about issues on the Homewood Campus on Wednesday

Richardson Meets
Students Face to Face
by Alex Varon
Close to twenty undergraduates
attended President William
Richardson's open forum on
Wednesday to voice concerns
about issues on the Homewood
Campus. The open forums are an
opportunity for students to meet
face to face with the University
President.
"I just wanted to set aside a
time for faculty and students to
say hello and discuss issues which
they might find important," said
Richardson at the beginning of
the forum.
The forum was very informal,
with students perched on chairs
and couches in a circle around the
President.
"This idea is still experimental," Richardson explained.
"We'll keep trying until we find
a format which works best."
Students who attended included student council members and
club presidents, as well as
students who were simply interested in campus issues. A
variety of topics were discussed,
ranging from security to the needs
of minority students.
Richardson began the session
by explaining the work in which
he is currently involved:
fundraising.
"The outside world is important to the University," he said.

—The time away from campus
removes me from some of the internal operations of Hopkins, but
since the outside world is important in contributing funds, I have
to do it. It is very important to the
University in order to allow it to
keep doing what it is doing."
Security was a major concern
raised for discussion. Items mentioned were the construction in
Krieger Hall, patrols and jurisdiction, the security vans, and campus lighting.
"I walked around campus a
couple of nights ago," Richardson said, "and noticed that [the
freshman quad] was one of the
least lit places on campus."
Another subject that was
brought up was the question of
minorities on campus, including
the role played by minority faculty and Afro-American studies.
"The only way of dealing with
bringing in more minority professors, that I know, is active
recruiting," stated Richardson.
"I think this will help us get the
larger racial mix that I'd like to
see here."
Richardson said that no plans
have been made for an AfroAmerican studies area major, but
pointed out that the University
has been working on the
establishment of a Woman's
Studies program and minor.

Proposed at Council

Black Students Blame
Ethnocentric Campus

by Matt Rosengart

by Marc Hochstein

Student Council focused on
current proposals at this week's
meeting. Roxanne Tena,
sophomore class president,
presented a proposal for a schoolwide croquet tournament. Discussion of a possible entrance fee and
the prize size followed. The
overall tournament is estimated to
cost $1070, with $200 to be allotted for the prize. It was decided
that an entrance fee will be
waived to maximize student participation. The tentative date for
the event is April 6. Teams will
consist of five members and the
tournament will proceed on a
first- come-first-serve basis. The
proposal passed by a majority
vote.
A proposal was also made addressing the budgeting process of
Council and the SAC. The proposal would construct a new committee, the Finance Committee,
comprised of six members of
Council, one student at large to
be appointed by Council president, and the director of Student
Activities.
The proposal addressed what it
called the unconstitutional manner in which budgeting had been
conducted in the past five years
and was aimed at making the
committee that allots money for
student groups a body accountable to students.
At present, the SAC Executive
Board is that body, but it is not
elected by the students directly.
This committee would include
one member from each class of
Council, along with that appointed by the president and the
Student Council Treasurer, according to the proposal.
Some members thought that adding the Student Activities Director would dilute the principle of
student accountability and selfgovernance. Other problems
discussed was the need for a student referendum. To conserve
money and time, certain sections

of the Elections Committee's
Constitution would be suspended
to have the referendum during the
Council Executive Board run-off
election.
Craig Freeman, the treasurer of
Student Council and chairman of
the SAC Executive Board, objected, saying that present procedures have functioned
smoothly. Others felt that suspending the Elections Committee's constitution would negate
past attempts to keep Council and
the Election Board separate.
Ultimately, the proposal failed as
a result of considerable objection.

Your Housing or Mine?
It's that time of year again: time for freshmen to find the
place that they will call "home" next year. It's also time for
upperclassmen who don't like their current residence to find
a more suitable one. But is University housing the answer?
As we are in the midst of the housing lottery, the push for
University buildings is stronger than ever—especially with the
newly renovated Bradford Apartments and the yet-to-becompleted Wolman Hall. There are definite advantages to
University housing, but there are also considerable drawbacks.
It is these shortcomings that the University quite understandably
wishes to ignore, yet students must consider the "big picture"
before they possibly sign onto a sinking ship.
After a noisy round of renovations, Wolman Hall has suddenly become God's gift to housing: the University cannot spout
enough platitudes to applaud the "new improved" Wolman.
Of course this building will catch the average student's eye;
however, even a new building can have its share of problems.
Case in point—the Bradford. Leaky pipes and malfunctioning
elevators are far from rare. Not even The Johns Hopkins
University can guarantee your apartment will be trouble-free.
A misconception provoked by the word new is that it means
better. The old Wolman featured very large rooms for the price.
They may not have been the most attractive, but made up for
it in square footage. The new Wolman will no doubt be larger
and nicer—but a great deal smaller as far as individual rooms
go. While there is no furniture in Wolman as yet, one student
has reported that some of the rooms in the Bradford are so tiny
that a couch-bed cannot be opened all the way.
Students should also think about the University's position in
the Wolman affair. Mandatory sophomore housing begins with
next year's freshman class. That means that the University has
a vested interest in filling Wolman to the brim with any living,
breathing, rent-paying individual next year because it needs to
begin paying its ever-increasing construction costs. It's plain
and simple: the University is desperate.
The issue here is that Hopkins is not necessarily interested

in your needs. It has a goal that must be reached. Therefore,
students—and especially current freshmen—are being caught
in the numbers game. Unfortunately, those numbers are still
unavailable. Rates for Wolman rentals have not been posted
yet for a reason. The University doesn't want to scare off
students early in the game. Rowhouses are more reasonable
than almost anything around, but they go fast, and students will
soon be tight on time. The University is aware of this.
Proximity to campus is another feature of University housing that is not unique. You do not have to live at the Carlyle
or far down on 29th Street if you don't opt for University housing. Your options are open: apartment, rowhouse, condominium. Yes, condominium. Some condo buildings are unofficially renting to students now. To take one example: three
Hopkins students live just a few blocks away from campus in
a very large two-bedroom condo and pay $300 plus utilities
each a month. That is cheaper than some apartment buildings,
and the security and privacy are better. If you don't have the
money to spend, three people can rent a three-bedroom
rowhouse apartment for $233 each plus utilities per month.
So what are the right reasons for choosing University housing? One is that you want to—not because the University strongly suggests that you do. Another is that you want to live in a
dorm-like atmosphere with your friends. Wolman would be
perfect for this, but the Bradford is an apartment building, and
therefore might not suit your needs. One rule to live by:
whenever possible, talk to other students who are living in the
building that interests you. Find out the advantages and disadvantages. Ask them to be specific. "It's nice" doesn't tell you
much about the building.
Don't be misled into believing that you won't have any friends
if you don't live in University housing, either. Chances are that
your friends will be living in the Charles Village area close
to campus. If it's worth the extra bucks every month to be able
to see and smell them, then you might want to live in University housing.

To the Editors:
It is my understanding that it
against IFC rules for fraternities and
sororities to charge money upon entrance to their parties. Since this
practice is often flagrantly violated,
why are attempts not made to enforce it? This past Saturday night!
went to both the TEP and the DU

the fraternity grossed approximately $1000. Even after the costs of the

they still made a significant amount

money.
Fraternities at Johns Hopkins enjoy various privileges that
distinguish them from the rest of the
student population. As such, they
should be required to abide by the

David Redish and Anuj Gupta
The Johns Hopkins University throws away 500 tons of
garbage every year. The average
American throws away three and
a half pounds of garbage every
week, or half a ton per person per
year. We throw out more than
160 million tons of garbage every
year. Currently this garbage
either goes to a landfill, or to an
incinerator, or it gets recycled.
Half of the landfills in the
United States will be full by next
year. In New York City, four out
of six landfills are already closed. Garbage decays only very
slowly in landfills. Garbologists
have found newspapers from the
(
1940s which are still readable and
grass cuttings which ate still
green. Most landfills are not built
to contain toxic waste, and they
contaminate the ground water
nearby. All four of the closed
landfills in New York City are
currently listed by the state as
hazardous waste sites.
Incineration reduces the
volume to 25 percent, but incinerators produce sulfur dioxide
and nitrogen dioxide, the two major components in acid rain, and
hydrogen chloride, a very
poisonous acid gas. A study by
the Swedish government found
that 55 percent of all mercury in
its environment comes from incinerators. Incinerators have problems in general with heavy
metals, such as mercury. Since
they don't burn, these heavy
metals end up in the ash. Incinerator ash is very highly concentrated in toxins, and currently it goes straight to a landfill.
Incinerators are supposed to
create energy from the garbage,
but most of the heat generated in
an incinerator is wasted melting
metals in the garbage. Even the
best incinerators have an efficiency of only 15 percent. Many incinerators are so inefficient, that
in order to burn the garbage, one
must put in more energy than is
produced.
Baltimore has two incinerators
and has made a commitment of
one of the, RESCO,for 900 tons
of garbage every day. If the city
does not give RESCO this garbage, not only do we have to pay
for 900 tons, but the incinerator is
allowed to find this garbage
elsewhere. Somehow, RESCO
got a deal that if the pollution
standards change, any pollution
controls added will be paid for by
the city. How did we get trapped
into this dead end deal?
The economic potential of
recycling has been well proven.
Recyclable goods are a commodity, a natural resource. If a person in Baltimore throws away an
aluminum can, and it ends up in
a landfill, then that aluminum is
out of circulation, 'and more
aluminum will have to be mined
and smelted to be made into
another can. If the can goes into
an incinerator, then not only is
that aluminum out of circulation,
we have wasted energy melting
it. If, on the other hand, the
aluminum is kept within the
Baltimore economy, there are
jobs created in Baltimore, jobs
collecting the recyclables, jobs
working them into a useable
form, and jobs making the new
products. Recycling one
aluminum can saves the energy
equivalent to that can half full of
gasoline, or 95 percent of the
energy used to make a new can
from raw materials. Every year,
more than six tons of aluminum
is sold from Hopkins vending
machines.
Johns Hopkins began recycling
last year when the Students for
Environmental Action (SEA)
began an aluminum recyclying
program. The program was so.
successful that the University
created JHU Recycles, run joinity
by the SEA and Custodial Services, which currently recycles
25 percent of the Hopkins waste
stream. In February, the SEA did
a project in which student sorted
through all of the University's
trash for one week and found that
at least 63 percent of the Hopkins
waste stream could be recycled.
Currently it costs Hopkins
more than $85 per ton to send its

garbage to an incinerator or a
landfill. Since the market pays for
white paper, aluminum, and
glass, and takes cardboard, tin
and low-grade paper for free, if
Hopkins recycled this 63 percent
of its waste stream, it would save
over $40,000 each year.
Not only does recycling work
on an institutional level, but some
states and cities have found

recycling to be an economic
boon. New York's bottle bill,
which puts a deposit on each bottle, saved New York $50 million
in clean-up costs, $19 million in
solid waste costs, and bettween
$50 and $100 million in energy
costs. Because of the bottle bill
in Iowa, 92 percent of bottles sold
in Iowa are reused or recycled.
Many places have curbside
recycling, where one puts out
recycleables in a special container
next to one's garbage. In parts of

FELLOWSHIP:
THREE $5000 SCHOLARSHIPS
Applications are currently being taken for the Louis
Azrael Fellowship in Communications, 3 one-year, $5000
scholarship for students who have demonstrated
excellence in journalism, radio, television, or other kinds
of public communications.
The fellowship, won in recent years by Hopkins'
students Elizabeth Brown, Sharyn Horowitz, Joshua
Orenstein, Kimberly Lankford, Alexandra Pham,
Thomas Kern, Dyanna Phillips, Nancy Schnall, Jeffrey
Pruzan, Mira Vayda and Mark Friedman, honors the
memory of Louis Azrael, a nationally known columnist
for the now defunct Baltimore News American. Azrael
was a Baltimore newsman for nearly sixty years and was
distinguished for his work during World War II,
especially for his account of D-Day. His war
correspondence won him a Medal of Freedom from
President Dwight D. Eisenhower.
The Azrael award is given through The Writing
Seminars, and will be judged by Professors Stephen
Dixon, Mark Crispin Miller, Theo Lippman, and
Herbert Altschull. As Hopkins has no official
communications program, students in any department,
who are considering a career in the media, are .invited to
apply.
Applicants for the award must be Hopkins sophomores
or juniors, and must be nominated by a faculty member.
This may come in the form of a direct nomination by
the faculty member, or a self-nomination by the student
with a letter of recommendation from a faculty member.
Students should submit a portfolio of supporting
material of 15-30 pages, a brief bio, a statement about
current interests, and some prospectus for future plans
along with their letter of sponsorship, to The Writing
Seminars, 136 Gilman by Friday, March 29th, 3:00pm.
For more information please contact Professor Dixon.

Hopkins Celebrates Women's History
Month With Events Throughout March
by Kristina Schake
Johns Hopkins commemorates
Women's History Month this
March with a month-long series
of events intended to raise the
profile of women and analyze
gender issues. A member of the
organizing committee, graduate
student Kathy Fuller, explained,
"The idea of Women's History
Month is as old as the women's
movement, starting in the late
1960s, but this month's events are
new to Hopkins. There is a new
level of awareness of gender in

at least some parts of the Hopkins
community at the moment, partly due to the recent establishment
of the Women's Studies program
and the arrival of Professor Judy
Walkowitz as its director. The
events of Women's History
Month have been organized by
students in hopes of including the
whole Hopkins community."
A wide variety of events
designed to appeal to a broad
spectrum of the Hopkins community are planned for the entire
month, including roundtable
discussions, public lectures, a

film series, a coffeehouse concert
and a book display. An art installation entitled "So Much
Choice" will be in the lounge
area of Levering Hall all this
month. Created by Professor
Pamela Blotner of the University of Maryland-College Park, it
represents the choices women
must face, between career and
family, home and work, and the
dangers and benefits their decisions involve.

Habitat for Humanity Restores
Houses, Hope for Poor Families
by Alex Pham
Once a shelter for families, the
house has deteriorated into a convenient stop for the neighborhood
dopeheads to shoot heroin. The
yard is caked with the filth of
ghetto life—hypodermic needles,
empty liquor bottles and pennies
rusted beyond recognition, buried
dreams of a better existence.
But then a group of people
visited, smiled at the condemned
house, and vowed to turn it into
a home again. The group, called
Habitat for Humanity, adopted it
along with six of its sister
rowhouses a few doors down the
block. One of the neighboring
houses suffered crippling damage
when a fire claimed nearly every
structural support it had. In that
sense, this house was lucky; it
was salvageable.
But not by much. When a
group of fifteen Hopkins students
volunteered to fix up the place
two Saturdays ago, its floors were
rotted, its basement flooded with
green water, its walls ripped out
and its roof sagging from the
winter rain.
"Your job is to go up to the second floor and rip out the floor,"
said Habitat Foreman John
McCormick to the Hopkins
volunteers.

Okay, the Hopkins students
said to themselves. But then what
do we stand on?
"Suspension cables," joked
Kobi Little who was there with
his fraternity, Alpha Phi Alpha.
The only access to the second
floor was an unreliable-looking
ladder sitting on top of a board
that covered a hole in the floor.
Below swam primordial creatures
of questionable character.
Armed with their hands, two
hammers, and crowbars, Hoppies
were able to apply the laws of
physics to pry off the floorboards,
strip by strip, then tossing them
out the window. While some
were working off the pressure of
schoolwork, others were inspired
by a prospect that the house
would some day be new and
owned by a small family.
"I was wondering what it was
going to look like, and how the
family was going to feel when
they moved in," said Little.
"They'll never know that I was
there to help. . .but it was good
to just do some old-fashioned
hard work. I didn't mind that it
was freezing and dirty. It was fun
to just get out there and do
something worthwhile."
Freshman Justin Szlasa also
liked the hands-on experience. "I
felt I was accomplishing

something," Szlasa said. "I
didn't realize how bad [the condition of these houses] were until I saw the insides of the houses
and all the garbage piled on the
roofs of houses. And to see that
things can be changed is really
heartening."
The Hopkins group was
organized by Scott Marks, who
runs a campus volunteer program
called the Group for Civic Progress, and Roxanne Tena, the
sophomore class president.
"As students living in the city, I felt we had to try to give
something back to the community," said Tena.
Tena said she was encouraged
when most of those who came expressed an interest in continuing
the rehabilitation.
While nearly all of the
rehabilitation is volunteerpowered, the cost of renovating
one home in Baltimore can reach
$25,000. Although the amount is
small relative to the cost of
similar homes renovated by forprofit developers, Habitat cannot
afford to give them away, said
Darci Ann Morris, Habitat's
Volunteer Director.
Instead, families who purchase
the homes receive a no-interest
mortgage, whose payments are
based on a sliding scale. Monthly

"Cystic Fibrosis is the most
common lethal inherited disorder
in the Caucasian population,"
said Dr. Garry Cutting, M.D., an
assistant professor of pediatrics at
The Johns Hopkins Children's
Center. The disease remains the
predominant cause of chronic
lung disease in children and accounts for a large proportion of
chronic pancreatic, liver and
sinus disease in this same age
group.
Although the disease claims
about 400 lives a year, approximately 1 in every 25 Caucasian
individuals carries the defective
CF gene. Over 17,000 people in
the United States have been
diagnosed with cystic fibrosis
but the actual number of cases remains uncertain. Since carriers
for this disorder are healthy,
many are, as yet, unaware that
they have the disease and the
disease is usually only discovered
when the carrier has an affected
child.
Cystic Fibrosis is characterized by thick, viscous mucous
which plugs up airways in the
lungs and ducts within the pancreas, leading to infection and the
progressive destruction of both
organs. The mucous itself is
similar to the muscous that one
suffers from during a common
cold. The sweat glands are the
third major part of the body that
are affected. The electrolyte content of the sweat of CF individuals is high and can eventually lead to salt loss and severe
dehydration.
The strange composition of
sweat was one of the first tip-offs
that scientists had almost 40 years
ago to recognize the presence of
CF in their patients. The biggest
signs came from the excessive
amounts of mucous that the patient often coughed up, irregular
eating habits, and dehydration.

to
the

a little bit wild. and we took advantage of that."

stopiied, turned, planted and fired
a blast past Bacigalupo with 33

the Jays could have generated
quickly evaporated as the Tigers
scored seventeen seconds into the
fourth quarter. Wills came back
to score for the Jays before
Tierney added his second and
Adam Wright scored two.
However, it was a case of too little, too late.
For the Jays to be successful,
the middies will have to wctrk on
moving without the ball and getting it to players behind the cage
to set up the offense. Seaman
observed that classifying a game
as upbeat might not best suit the
current Hopkins squad. Ball control at certain times, such as
Princeton's run, might better help
settle a frustrated offensive team.
Although Princeton was a
physically faster team, Dwan
noted that it's not the speed that
makes the difference but the
heart. "We have to hustle, get the
ground balls, prevent turnovers
and use some ball control. We
just played defense for too long,"
commented Dwan. It sounds like
Hopkins can take a page out of
the New York Giants playbook.
Establish an early lead, play
tough defense, especially in goal,
control the ball and capitalize on

their opponents' failures when
pressing to catch up. — We have
to rebound and move on and not
dwell on this game. We're still
adjusting to a new system and
there are ten games left," Dwan
concluded.
After Giardina and Hobbs were
scorched for fifteen goals, the
starting job will be decided in
practice. Expect Giardina to have
a slight edge since it is tough to
replace a starter after one game
unless the backup performs
outstandingly. Additionally, the
midfield will have to make better decisions with and without the
ball. One area in which the midfield suffered terribly was getting
out of position and being beaten
on fast break clears or unsettled
situations. Seaman will work with
the midfielders trying to teach
them to recognize certain situations and the appropriate
response. "We definitely learned some things about ourselves
and what we can do," concluded Seaman. Finally, one area
over which the team has little
control and much to be concerned about is officiating. Hopkins
usually has the same incompetent
crew for most of their home
games. The only consolation
might be that they missed calls
both ways, although the bad calls
(or no-calls) hurt the Jays far
more than the Tigers.

Close to twenty undergraduates
attended President William

time for faculty and students to
say hello and discuss issues which
they might find important," said
Richardson at the beginning of
the forum.
The forum was very informal,
with students perched on chairs
and couches in a circle around the
President.
"This idea is still experimental," Richardson explained.
"We'll keep trying until we find
a format which works best."
Students who attended included student council members and
club presidents, as well as
students who were simply interested in campus issues. A
variety of topics were discussed,
ranging from security to the needs
of minority students.
Richardson began the session
by explaining the work in which
he is currently involved:
fundraising.
"The outside world is important to the University," he said.

—The time away from campus
removes me from some of the internal operations of Hopkins, but
since the outside world is important in contributing funds, I have
to do it. It is very important to the
University in order to allow it to
keep doing what it is doing."
Security was a major concern
raised for discussion. Items mentioned were the construction in
Krieger Hall, patrols and jurisdiction, the security vans, and campus lighting.
"I walked around campus a
couple of nights ago," Richardson said, "and noticed that [the
freshman quad] was one of the
least lit places on campus."
Another subject that was
brought up was the question of
minorities on campus, including
the role played by minority faculty and Afro-American studies.
"The only way of dealing with
bringing in more minority professors, that I know, is active
recruiting," stated Richardson.
"I think this will help us get the
larger racial mix that I'd like to
see here."

Your Housing or Mine?
It's that time of year again: time for freshmen to find the
place that they will call "home" next year. It's also time for
upperclassmen who don't like their current residence to find
a more suitable one. But is University housing the answer?
As we are in the midst of the housing lottery, the push for
University buildings is stronger than ever—especially with the
newly renovated Bradford Apartments and the yet-to-becompleted Wolman Hall. There are definite advantages to
University housing, but there are also considerable drawbacks.
It is these shortcomings that the University quite understandably
wishes to ignore, yet students must consider the "big picture"
before they possibly sign onto a sinking ship.
After a noisy round of renovations, Wolman Hall has suddenly become God's gift to housing: the University cannot spout
enough platitudes to applaud the "new improved" Wolman.
Of course this building will catch the average student's eye;
however, even a new building can have its share of problems.
Case in point—the Bradford. Leaky pipes and malfunctioning
elevators are far from rare. Not even The Johns Hopkins
University can guarantee your apartment will be trouble-free.
A misconception provoked by the word new is that it means
better. The old Wolman featured very large rooms for the price.
They may not have been the most attractive, but made up for
it in square footage. The new Wolman will no doubt be larger
and nicer—but a great deal smaller as far as individual rooms
go. While there is no furniture in Wolman as yet, one student
has reported that some of the rooms in the Bradford are so tiny
that a couch-bed cannot be opened all the way.
Students should also think about the University's position in
the Wolman affair. Mandatory sophomore housing begins with
next year's freshman class. That means that the University has
a vested interest in filling Wolman to the brim with any living,
breathing, rent-paying individual next year because it needs to
begin paying its ever-increasing construction costs. It's plain
and simple: the University is desperate.
The issue here is that Hopkins is not necessarily interested

in your needs. It has a goal that must be reached. Therefore,
students—and especially current freshmen—are being caught
in the numbers game. Unfortunately, those numbers are still
unavailable. Rates for Wolman rentals have not been posted
yet for a reason. The University doesn't want to scare off
students early in the game. Rowhouses are more reasonable
than almost anything around, but they go fast, and students will
soon be tight on time. The University is aware of this.
Proximity to campus is another feature of University housing that is not unique. You do not have to live at the Carlyle
or far down on 29th Street if you don't opt for University housing. Your options are open: apartment, rowhouse, condominium. Yes, condominium. Some condo buildings are unofficially renting to students now. To take one example: three
Hopkins students live just a few blocks away from campus in
a very large two-bedroom condo and pay $300 plus utilities
each a month. That is cheaper than some apartment buildings,
and the security and privacy are better. If you don't have the
money to spend, three people can rent a three-bedroom
rowhouse apartment for $233 each plus utilities per month.
So what are the right reasons for choosing University housing? One is that you want to—not because the University strongly suggests that you do. Another is that you want to live in a
dorm-like atmosphere with your friends. Wolman would be
perfect for this, but the Bradford is an apartment building, and
therefore might not suit your needs. One rule to live by:
whenever possible, talk to other students who are living in the
building that interests you. Find out the advantages and disadvantages. Ask them to be specific. "It's nice" doesn't tell you
much about the building.
Don't be misled into believing that you won't have any friends
if you don't live in University housing, either. Chances are that
your friends will be living in the Charles Village area close
to campus. If it's worth the extra bucks every month to be able
to see and smell them, then you might want to live in University housing.

To the Editors:
It is my understanding that it
against IFC rules for fraternities and
sororities to charge money upon entrance to their parties. Since this
practice is often flagrantly violated,
why are attempts not made to enforce it? This past Saturday night!
went to both the TEP and the DU
parties and was required to pay $3

similar explanation at DU.

fraternity parties from being moneymaking ventures. I figure that if 350
people attend a fraternity party, then
the fraternity grossed approximately $1000. Even after the costs of the
D.J. and the kegs of beer (for which
they were responsible for paying),
they still made a significant amount
of money. This is unjustly collected
money.
Fraternities at Johns Hopkins enjoy various privileges that
distinguish them from the rest of the
student population. As such, they
should be required to abide by the
very guidelines of conduct which
they helped establish.
I do not mean TEP or DU. They
are not the only ones which charge
money at the door. Unfortunately,
most fraternities require "mandatory
donations"(with recent notable exceptions being Sig Ep, Kappa
Sigma, Pi Lambda Phi, and Phi Si).

Paying money to socialize at
Hopkins, where there are so few
organized social events to begin
with, is an exclusionary practice,
whose prohibition ought to be enforced. When will this happen?

The Johns Hopkins University throws away 500 tons of
garbage every year. The average
American throws away three and
a half pounds of garbage every
week, or half a ton per person per
year. We throw out more than
160 million tons of garbage every
year. Currently this garbage
either goes to a landfill, or to an
incinerator, or it gets recycled.
Half of the landfills in the
United States will be full by next
year. In New York City, four out

FELLOWSHIP:
THREE $5000 SCHOLARSHIPS
Applications are currently being taken for the Louis
Azrael Fellowship in Communications, 3 one-year, $5000
scholarship for students who have demonstrated
excellence in journalism, radio, television, or other kinds
of public communications.
The fellowship, won in recent years by Hopkins'
students Elizabeth Brown, Sharyn Horowitz, Joshua
Orenstein, Kimberly Lankford, Alexandra Pham,
Thomas Kern, Dyanna Phillips, Nancy Schnall, Jeffrey
Pruzan, Mira Vayda and Mark Friedman, honors the
memory of Louis Azrael, a nationally known columnist
for the now defunct Baltimore News American. Azrael
was a Baltimore newsman for nearly sixty years and was
distinguished for his work during World War II,
especially for his account of D-Day. His war
correspondence won him a Medal of Freedom from
President Dwight D. Eisenhower.
The Azrael award is given through The Writing
Seminars, and will be judged by Professors Stephen
Dixon, Mark Crispin Miller, Theo Lippman, and
Herbert Altschull. As Hopkins has no official
communications program, students in any department,
who are considering a career in the media, are .invited to
apply.
Applicants for the award must be Hopkins sophomores
or juniors, and must be nominated by a faculty member.
This may come in the form of a direct nomination by
the faculty member, or a self-nomination by the student
with a letter of recommendation from a faculty member.
Students should submit a portfolio of supporting
material of 15-30 pages, a brief bio, a statement about
current interests, and some prospectus for future plans
along with their letter of sponsorship, to The Writing
Seminars, 136 Gilman by Friday, March 29th, 3:00pm.
For more information please contact Professor Dixon.

Habitat for Humanity Restores
Houses, Hope for Poor Families
by Alex Pham
Once a shelter for families, the
house has deteriorated into a convenient stop for the neighborhood
dopeheads to shoot heroin. The
yard is caked with the filth of
ghetto life—hypodermic needles,
empty liquor bottles and pennies
rusted beyond recognition, buried
dreams of a better existence.
But then a group of people
visited, smiled at the condemned
house, and vowed to turn it into
a home again. The group, called
Habitat for Humanity, adopted it
along with six of its sister
rowhouses a few doors down the
block. One of the neighboring
houses suffered crippling damage
when a fire claimed nearly every
structural support it had. In that
sense, this house was lucky; it
was salvageable.
But not by much. When a
group of fifteen Hopkins students
volunteered to fix up the place
two Saturdays ago, its floors were
rotted, its basement flooded with
green water, its walls ripped out
and its roof sagging from the
winter rain.
"Your job is to go up to the second floor and rip out the floor,"
said Habitat Foreman John
McCormick to the Hopkins
volunteers.

Okay, the Hopkins students
said to themselves. But then what
do we stand on?
"Suspension cables," joked
Kobi Little who was there with
his fraternity, Alpha Phi Alpha.
The only access to the second
floor was an unreliable-looking
ladder sitting on top of a board
that covered a hole in the floor.
Below swam primordial creatures
of questionable character.
Armed with their hands, two
hammers, and crowbars, Hoppies
were able to apply the laws of
physics to pry off the floorboards,
strip by strip, then tossing them
out the window. While some
were working off the pressure of
schoolwork, others were inspired
by a prospect that the house
would some day be new and
owned by a small family.
"I was wondering what it was
going to look like, and how the
family was going to feel when
they moved in," said Little.
"They'll never know that I was
there to help. . .but it was good
to just do some old-fashioned
hard work. I didn't mind that it
was freezing and dirty. It was fun
to just get out there and do
something worthwhile."
Freshman Justin Szlasa also
liked the hands-on experience. "I
felt I was accomplishing

something," Szlasa said. "I
didn't realize how bad [the condition of these houses] were until I saw the insides of the houses
and all the garbage piled on the
roofs of houses. And to see that
things can be changed is really
heartening."
The Hopkins group was
organized by Scott Marks, who
runs a campus volunteer program
called the Group for Civic Progress, and Roxanne Tena, the
sophomore class president.
"As students living in the city, I felt we had to try to give
something back to the community," said Tena.
Tena said she was encouraged
when most of those who came expressed an interest in continuing
the rehabilitation.
While nearly all of the
rehabilitation is volunteerpowered, the cost of renovating
one home in Baltimore can reach
$25,000. Although the amount is
small relative to the cost of
similar homes renovated by forprofit developers, Habitat cannot
afford to give them away, said
Darci Ann Morris, Habitat's
Volunteer Director.
Instead, families who purchase
the homes receive a no-interest
mortgage, whose payments are
based on a sliding scale. Monthly

"Cystic Fibrosis is the most
common lethal inherited disorder
in the Caucasian population,"
said Dr. Garry Cutting, M.D., an
assistant professor of pediatrics at
The Johns Hopkins Children's
Center. The disease remains the
predominant cause of chronic
lung disease in children and accounts for a large proportion of
chronic pancreatic, liver and
sinus disease in this same age
group.
Although the disease claims
about 400 lives a year, approximately 1 in every 25 Caucasian
individuals carries the defective
CF gene. Over 17,000 people in
the United States have been
diagnosed with cystic fibrosis
but the actual number of cases remains uncertain. Since carriers
for this disorder are healthy,
many are, as yet, unaware that
they have the disease and the
disease is usually only discovered
when the carrier has an affected
child.
Cystic Fibrosis is characterized by thick, viscous mucous
which plugs up airways in the
lungs and ducts within the pancreas, leading to infection and the
progressive destruction of both
organs. The mucous itself is
similar to the muscous that one

cold. The sweat glands are the
third major part of the body that

dehydration.
The strange composition of
sweat was one of the first tip-offs
that scientists had almost 40 years
ago to recognize the presence of
CF in their patients. The biggest
signs came from the excessive
amounts of mucous that the patient often coughed up, irregular
eating habits, and dehydration.
